ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Some of the lectures were extremely interesting, however others were not related to my research interests and in such a 'niche' part of the field that they were largely irrelevant. I am happy to have attended most of these lectures though.
You don't have any tasks for the class, but you can get an idea of what people are doing and discuss with them.
Obviously the quality of the presentations varied much between the different speakers. If logistics allow for it, it would be worth consider the introduction of a theme.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Cutting edge research presented by the authors themselves.
It's very interactive and interesting.
All in all it gave a good introduction to different research projects in environmental economics.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Nothing. Course is well planned and run.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: the research topics presented relate to the topics I would like to research in the future.

This course fits very well into the overall program. It is a great way to get exposure to the different ways that researchers in the field are conducting research and using theoretical tools from the classroom to contribute uniquely to the field.
I wouldn't recommend this course to students who don't have a strong background in economics.
The course is required for PhD students in environmental and resource economics. It is a seminar series that is also open to the public.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interesting and relevant to my desired career.
interested in research in environmental economics
To learn about the different types of research being done in the field of env econ.
I wanted to get more familiar with economic theories and terminology. I picked up a lot of this through the course, but so much of it went over my head that it wasn't time well spent.
See question 17.
To gain exposure to current research.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, it gave a good insight into current research projects.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course! Very low work load but a lot of value gained.
try to review papers/abstracts if available prior to the seminar. do not take until you've had advanced economics coursework.
Definitely reserve time for reading the papers before the presentations. It isn't as useful and interesting just to sit in.
